message: I went into the room on the front left.
The inside is just as messed up as it looked from outside.
Even though the door's only partly burned, how the hell did the inside end up in such a messed up state?
I went into the room in the front left.
Even though the door kept its original shape despite definitely showing signs of burning, why the hell is the inside of the room in such a terrible state？
Various relics are scattered across the floor.
Apparently, it wasn't just a storage-like room, but a room that must have served some important purpose.
There are cracks in the wall, like the remnants of a hole big enough for a tall person to walk through without ducking.
Maybe it's because of the fire, but cracks run from the floor to the ceiling, and in places the plaster is peeling off.
It's kind of weird, like there was an entrance carved into the wall, with cracks in the shape of a doorway.
Seeing that it's stained black and dirty just like the other parts, it probably isn't a hole that was patched up later, but I can't believe it's just a coincidence either.
I try pushing hard against the wall, but that much isn't going to do anything.
Next door should've been the room with rubble piled up in front of the door.
If only this wall would collapse, I could get into the next room...
Looks like it’s impossible for me.
There's a big crack in the wall.
I really hope it doesn't collapse while we're in the room.
There's a big crack in the wall.
It looks like the mortar wall is starting to give way under the weight of the ceiling.
Judging by the direction, the other side of this wall is inside the dirt, so it's hard to imagine there's some kind of hidden room ahead.
The crack in the ceiling feels ominous.
Feels like I'm a miner afraid of a cave-in...
Just thinking about the heavy stone-covered ground above this ceiling sends chills down my spine.
Since it's been left abandoned for over 100 years after the fire, it wouldn't be weird if it collapsed at any moment.
Plaster peeled off the wall is piled up on the floor.
Looks like it came off naturally.
Chunks of plaster are piled up on the floor.
The white fragments, probably peeled from where cracks formed in the wall, look like pieces of broken ceramics.
The room next door should've been blocked off by rubble at the entrance, making it impossible to get in. If only this wall was broken, I could get into the room‥‥‥‥
It's an old handwritten manuscript that survived the burning.
Doesn't seem to be worth much, let's leave it here.
It's a pretty old book.
To think something could survive a horrible fire like this...
I picked up a book that was lying on the floor.
The cover made of tanned and dyed leather is scorched in places, to the point where even the title can't be read.
It looks like it's from a time when printing technology wasn't common and books were expensive, and inside, it's a handwritten manuscript. Maybe a devoted Nun carefully copied it all by hand.
It seems to be written in Latin, but there are so many burn marks and smudges that I can barely read it.
If only I'd thrown myself into language studies more seriously back in my student days......
Since it's in the Monastery, it's probably a Bible or something, but it's weird that just this one book happened to survive the fire.
I don't really think it's worth much.
I put the book back on the floor.
It looks like experimental equipment made of melted glass.
I have no idea why something like this is lying around in the Monastery's basement.
It's a melted glass bottle.
It's shaped like a beaker used in scientific experiments.
Why is something like this in the Monastery's basement？
I picked up the glass bottle that had melted, leaving only the bottom part.
The glass, which melted from the heat and then solidified again, has deformed into a strange, shapeless form like water spilled on the floor.
I wonder who used something like this.
A Nun secretly sitting in a basement with experimental equipment goes way beyond anything I could imagine.
Looking at the floor, there's a huge amount of glass that's melted and doesn't have its original shape at all.
Weren't there a lot of other glass instruments too?
So this room was a Laboratory？
Why is there a room like that in the basement of the Monastery......
I have no fucking clue what's going on.
I wonder what other rooms there are.
Go outside
